name: Polyethylene (LDPE)
overview: A flexible, low-crystallinity polyethylene used in films and packaging.
uses: Plastic bags, films, squeeze bottles, wire and cable jacketing.
properties: Good toughness and clarity; lower density than HDPE.
safety: Generally low toxicity as a solid; avoid fumes from overheating. Consult SDS.

name: Polyethylene (HDPE)
overview: High crystallinity polyethylene with excellent chemical resistance.
manufacturing: Ziegler–Natta or metallocene catalysts under moderate pressure.
properties: High stiffness, good impact at low temperature; weldable.
safety: Solid HDPE is generally inert; thermal degradation releases irritant fumes.

name: Linear Low-Density Polyethylene (LLDPE)
safety: Consult the Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for the specific grade. Avoid fumes from combustion or overheating.

name: Polypropylene (PP)
overview: Lightweight, semi-crystalline thermoplastic with high fatigue resistance.
uses: Automotive trims, living hinges, packaging, fibers.
manufacturing: Ziegler–Natta or metallocene catalyzed polymerization of propylene.
properties: Low density, good chemical resistance; can be brittle at low temperature.
safety: Low acute toxicity; avoid fumes on overheating.

name: Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC)
overview: Versatile plastic; rigid PVC for pipes, plasticized PVC for flexible goods.
manufacturing: Suspension polymerization of vinyl chloride monomer (VCM).
properties: Flame retardant due to chlorine; rigid or flexible with plasticizers.
safety: Avoid burning or overheating which can release HCl and other irritants; follow SDS.

name: Polystyrene (PS)
overview: Amorphous, transparent thermoplastic; brittle unless modified.
uses: Disposable cutlery, CD cases, housings; EPS used as foam.
manufacturing: Bulk or suspension polymerization of styrene.
safety: Solid PS is low hazard; burning can release irritating fumes. EPS is flammable.

name: High Impact Polystyrene (HIPS)
safety: Consult the Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for the specific grade. Avoid fumes from combustion or overheating.

name: Expanded Polystyrene (EPS)
safety: Consult the Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for the specific grade. Avoid fumes from combustion or overheating.

name: Polyethylene Terephthalate (PET)
overview: Widely used polyester with good strength and barrier properties.
properties: Strong, transparent when amorphous; crystallizes on heating.
safety: As a solid, low hazard; avoid overheating and follow SDS.

name: PETG (Glycol-modified PET)
safety: Consult the Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for the specific grade. Avoid fumes from combustion or overheating.

name: Polybutylene Terephthalate (PBT)
safety: Consult the Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for the specific grade. Avoid fumes from combustion or overheating.

name: Polycarbonate (PC)
properties: High impact strength; transparent; sensitive to solvents.
safety: Avoid burning; some processes use BPA. Consult SDS.

name: Polyoxymethylene (POM, Acetal)
overview: Crystalline engineering plastic with low friction.
safety: Thermal degradation can release formaldehyde; process with care.

name: Polyamide 6 (PA6, Nylon 6)
overview: Engineering thermoplastic with good toughness and chemical resistance.
safety: Follow SDS; molten processing can emit fumes.

name: Polyamide 66 (PA66, Nylon 66)
overview: Higher melting nylon with good heat resistance.
properties: High strength and Tm; absorbs moisture.
safety: Follow SDS.

name: Polyether ether ketone (PEEK)
overview: High-performance thermoplastic with excellent mechanical and chemical resistance.
manufacturing: High-temperature step-growth polymerization in diphenyl sulfone.
properties: High Tm (~343°C), high modulus, chemical resistance.
safety: Generally stable; process at recommended temps to avoid degradation.

manufacturing: Ring-opening polymerization of lactide with metal catalysts.
properties: Rigid, clear; lower heat resistance unless crystallized or blended.
safety: Generally safe as a solid; industrial composting needed for rapid degradation.
